original_data.question: A 67-year-woman with non-Hodgkin lymphoma comes to the physician because of progressively increasing numbness and tingling in her fingers and toes. Her last cycle of chemotherapy with vincristine was 1 week ago. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch in all distal extremities. Knee and ankle deep tendon reflexes are decreased. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s peripheral neuropathy?

options.B: Creation of free radicals that unwind DNA
options.D: Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogues into DNA

model_response:
This patient’s peripheral neuropathy is an example of a dose-limiting toxicity of vincristine. Vincristine inhibits the formation of microtubules in cells by binding to and inhibiting the function of the polymerization of tubulin, a process necessary for the formation of microtubules. This disruption of microtubule formation inhibits cell division and can lead to apoptosis of the cell. The other choices are mechanisms of action of other classes of chemotherapeutic agents.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Any of a group of malignant tumors of lymphoid tissue that differ from HODGKIN DISEASE, being more heterogeneous with respect to malignant cell lineage, clinical course, prognosis, and therapy. The only common feature among these tumors is the absence of giant REED-STERNBERG CELLS, a characteristic of Hodgkin's disease.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Absent or reduced sensitivity to cutaneous stimulation.
Subjective cutaneous sensations (e.g., cold, warmth, tingling, pressure, etc.) that are experienced spontaneously in the absence of stimulation.
Four or five slender jointed digits in humans and primates, attached to each HAND.
Any one of five terminal digits of the vertebrate FOOT.
The use of DRUGS to treat a DISEASE or its symptoms. One example is the use of ANTINEOPLASTIC AGENTS to treat CANCER.
An antitumor alkaloid isolated from VINCA ROSEA. (Merck, 11th ed.)
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

The process in which specialized SENSORY RECEPTOR CELLS transduce peripheral stimuli (physical or chemical) into NERVE IMPULSES which are then transmitted to the various sensory centers in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.
The farthest or outermost projections of the body, such as the HAND and FOOT.
A region of the lower extremity immediately surrounding and including the KNEE JOINT.
The region of the lower limb between the FOOT and the LEG.

Contraction of a muscle triggered by a signal from a muscle spindle in response to a stimulus applied to a specific trigger point on the body. The strength of the response can provide insight into central and peripheral nerve performance.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.
The means by which an effect is obtained.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

A disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system. It manifests with pain, tingling, numbness, and muscle weakness. It may be the result of physical injury, toxic substances, viral diseases, diabetes, renal failure, cancer, and drugs.
